DOC.HEAD: Officers `Moved To Tears' By Homeless Man's Christmas Gifts
DOC.TEXT: Two police officers were on patrol when a man who looked like a haggard Santa Claus flagged them down from the side of the road, saying he had something to give them. The white-bearded man, dressed in worn overalls and a thinning jacket, led officers Michael Leonard and Ed McDaniel to his makeshift home _ a clapboard hideaway tucked beneath the stairwell of a warehouse _ and handed them two magnificently handcarved wooden toys. ``I want you to give these to a boy and a girl who would otherwise not have a good Christmas,'' Wayne Miller, 53, told the officers. ``We were moved to tears,'' Leonard said Friday as he recalled the recent encounter near the Marine Corps Recruit Depot. ``He had several other toys in various stages (of completion), and he seemed very disappointed that those would not be ready for Christmas.'' Miller revealed little about his personal life to the officers except that he has been living on the streets by his own choosing for 12 years. One of the toys, which he began carving last July, was an auto that could double as a jewelry box because of its compartments. The other was a tractor-trailor loaded with logs. ``He collected the materials to build the toys while digging through dumpsters for food and aluminum cans,'' Leonard said. ``At night, he carves the wood in front of his campfire.'' Leonard delivered the toys to the Department of Social Services Children's Center, where assistant deputy director Sherry Paul promised that workers would deliver the gifts to a family by today. The officers, meanwhile, started a collection to buy Miller a sleeping bag or warm jacket, despite Miller's insistence that he's doing fine.
